      Two-Dimensional Crystals from Reduced Symmetry Analogues of Trimesic Acid
      Barnard, Rachel A.; Dutta, Ananya; Schnobrich, Jennifer K.; Morrison, Christine N.; Ahn, Seokhoon; Matzger, Adam J.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (15), 5954-5961CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The two-dimensional assembly of multicarboxylated arenes is explored at the liq.-graphite interface using scanning tunneling microscopy. Symmetry variations were introduced via phenylene spacer addn. and the influence of these perturbations on the formation of H-bonded motifs from an alkanoic acid solvent is obsd. This work demonstrates the importance of symmetry in 2-dimensional crystal formation and draws possible links of this behavior to prediction of coordination modes in three-dimensional coordination polymers.

      (a) Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7– 13 DOI: 10.1107/S0021889802022112
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33a
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2
      (b) Spek, A. L. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. D: Biol. Crystallogr. 2009, 65, 148– 155 DOI: 10.1107/S090744490804362X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33b
      Structure validation in chemical crystallography
      Spek, Anthony L.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography (2009), 65 (2), 148-155CODEN: ABCRE6; ISSN:0907-4449. (International Union of Crystallography)
      A review. Automated structure validation was introduced in chem. crystallog. about 12 years ago as a tool to assist practitioners with the exponential growth in crystal structure analyses. Validation has since evolved into an easy-to-use checkCIF/PLATON web-based IUCr service. The result of a crystal structure detn. has to be supplied as a CIF-formatted computer-readable file. The checking software tests the data in the CIF for completeness, quality, and consistency. In addn., the reported structure is checked for incomplete anal., errors in the anal., and relevant issues to be verified. A validation report is generated in the form of a list of ALERTS on the issues to be cor., checked, or commented on. Structure validation has largely eliminated obvious problems with structure reports published in IUCr journals, such as refinement in a space group of too low symmetry. This paper reports on the current status of structure validation and possible future extensions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtVWhtL8%253D&md5=1cc05cd996f846a98b55ea09289af6a9
    34. 34
      Plater, M. J.; Roberts, A. J.; Marr, J.; Lachowski, E. E.; Howie, R. A. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans. 1998, 797– 802 DOI: 10.1039/a708189h
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34
      Hydrothermal synthesis and characterization of alkaline-earth metal salts of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid
      Plater, M. John; Roberts, Alexander J.; Marr, Jim; Lachowski, Eric E.; Howie, R. Alan
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1998), (5), 797-802CODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The reaction of MII acetate (M = Sr or Ba) with benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3btc) yielded crystals [M(Hbtc)(H2O)2]·0.5H2O. These compds. are isostructural as shown by x-ray single-crystal anal. and by x-ray powder diffraction patterns. The structures consist of alternating layers of parallel Hbtc anions and cations stacked along the c axis. The metal ions are coordinated by two bidentate carboxylate groups, three monodentate carboxylate groups and two H2O mols. giving an overall coordination no. of nine. Heating liberates 2.5 H2O mols. per formulas unit to give M(Hbtc) which can reversibly bind H2O reforming [M(Hbtc)(H2O)2]·0.5H2O.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A microporous luminescent europium metal-organic framework for nitro explosive sensing
      Zhou, Xinhui; Li, Honghui; Xiao, Hongping; Li, Liang; Zhao, Qiang; Yang, Tao; Zuo, Jinglin; Huang, Wei
      Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (16), 5718-5723CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A microporous metal-org. framework (MOF) Eu3(MFDA)4(NO3)(DMF)3 (I, H2MFDA = 9,9-dimethylfluorene-2,7-dicarboxylic acid) was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The I is a three-dimensional coordination polymer with pcu type rod-packing structure, through which 1D rhombic channels penetrate. The solvent-free form Ia could be obtained by direct heating of I. Both I and Ia exhibit high intensity red light emissions with high quantum yields and long luminescence lifetimes when excited at 336 nm at ambient temp. The potential of Ia for nitro explosive sensing is studied through luminescence quenching expts., which show that Ia is a potential luminescent sensory material for nitro explosives.

      A series of d10 metal coordination polymers based on a flexible bis(2-methylbenzimidazole) ligand and different carboxylates: synthesis, structures, photoluminescence and catalytic properties
      Hao, Jin-ming; Yu, Bao-yi; Van Hecke, Kristof; Cui, Guang-hua
      CrystEngComm (2015), 17 (11), 2279-2293CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      To explore the influence of different arom. polycarboxylates on the self-assembly and properties of d10 metal coordination frameworks, six coordination compds. contg. a flexible bis(2-methylbenzimidazole) (pbmb) ligand, formulated as [Ag2(pbmb)(2,6-napdc)]n (1), {[Zn(pbmb)(tbta)]·H2O}n (2), {[Cd(pbmb)(tbta)]·H2O}n (3), [Zn2(pbmb)(btec)(H2O)]n (4), {[Zn2(OH)(pbmb)(bpdc)1.5]·H2O}n (5), and [Cd(pbmb)(3-npa)(H2O)]n (6), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by physicochem. and spectroscopic methods as well as single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal. (2,6-H2napdc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, H2tbta = tetrabromoterephthalic acid, H4btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, H2bpdc = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid and H23-npa = 3-nitrophthalic acid). Complex 1 possesses an 8-connected 3D coordination framework with sqc3 topol. based on rare tetranuclear Ag(I)-cluster secondary building units (SBUs). 2 And 3 possess 2D (4,4) grid structures. 4 Shows a novel (3,4,5)-connected 2D network with the Schlafli symbol of {3·4·5}{3·42·52·6}{3·43·53·6·72}. 5 Features a uninodal (4,4)-connected net contg. binuclear {Zn2(OH)} SBUs and a 2-fold interpenetrating (3,6)-connected supramol. framework with {42·6}{44·610·8}-3,6T24 topol. that is formed via hydrogen bond interactions. Complex 6 is a 1D double-chain structure, which is finally extended to a 3D (4,5,5)-connected supramol. network via hydrogen bonding interactions. Complexes 1-6 indicate high thermal stabilities and different photoluminescence behavior in the solid state. Moreover, all of these polymer materials manifest excellent photocatalytic activities for the degrdn. of methyl orange in the photo-Fenton-like process after 120 min (1: 99%, 2: 66%, 3: 91%, 4: 83%, 5: 91% and 6: 93%, resp.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Two metal-organic frameworks with unique high-connected binodal network topologies: synthesis, structures, and catalytic properties
      Cui, Guang-Hua; He, Cui-Hong; Jiao, Cui-Huan; Geng, Jian-Chen; Blatov, Vladislav A.
      CrystEngComm (2012), 14 (12), 4210-4216CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      {[Cd3(btec)(btx)0.5(μ3-OH)(H2O)]·H2O}n (1) and [Cu2(btec)(btx)1.5]n (2), two novel cadmium(II) and copper(II)-based high-connected metal-org. frameworks, with both 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (btec) and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (btx) as mixed ligands were hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Both MOFs have three-dimensional (3D) structures, but different framework topologies and ligand linkage modes. 1 Possesses an unprecedented binodal (4,12)-connected topol. structure, in which the ligand btec serves as a rare dodecadentate and ordinary octadentate in two types of coordination modes. Meanwhile, 2 exhibits a binodal (4,7)-connected topol. network with an enneadentate coordination geometry of the btec ligand. Both MOFs provide novel examples of designing and synthesizing novel binodal MOFs, and demonstrate that the 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid ligand with rich coordination chem. information is useful in the construction of binodal highly-connected nets. In addn., the catalytic performance of 2 also was checked. 2 Is active as a catalyst for the degrdn. of methyl orange.

      Four cobalt(II) coordination polymers with diverse topologies derived from flexible bis(benzimidazole) and aromatic dicarboxylic acids: syntheses, crystal structures and catalytic properties
      Wang, Xiao Xiao; Yu, Baoyi; Van Hecke, Kristof; Cui, Guang Hua
      RSC Advances (2014), 4 (106), 61281-61289CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Four mixed ligand coordination polymers based on the flexible bis(5,6-dimethybenzimidazole) and arom. dicarboxylic acids, namely, [Co(L1)(bpdc)]n (1), {[Co(L1)(npht)]·1.5H2O}n (2), [Co(L2)(bpdc)]n (3), and [Co(L3)(bpdc)(H2O)]n (4) (L1 = 1,4-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, L2 = 1,3-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, H2npht = 3-nitrophthalic acid, L3 = 1,1'-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazole)methane) were hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Polymer 1 features a 3-dimensional 3-fold interpenetrating dia array with a 4-connected 66 network, while 2 exhibits a 3-dimensional noninterpenetrated 3-connected framework with a 103-ThSi2 architecture. 3 And 4 have two-dimensional 3-connected (63) and 4-connected (44.62) topologies, resp. Complex 4 ultimately is extended into an unusual 3-dimensional (3,5)-connected seh-3,5-P21/c supramol. network via O-H···O H bonding interactions. The fluorescence and catalytic properties of the complexes for the degrdn. of the Congo red azo dye in a Fenton-like process are reported.

      Synthesis, crystal structures, luminescence and catalytic properties of two d10 metal coordination polymers constructed from mixed ligands
      Wang, Xiao-xiao; Zhang, Ming-xi; Yu, Baoyi; Van Hecke, Kristof; Cui, Guang-hua
      Spectrochimica Acta, Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy (2015), 139 (), 442-448CODEN: SAMCAS; ISSN:1386-1425. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Two new coordination polymers [Cd(bmb)(hmph)]n (1), {[Ag(bmb)]·H2btc}n (2) (bmb = 1,4-bis(2-methylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, H2hmph = homophthalic acid, H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods, IR spectroscopy, TGA, XRPD and elemental anal. Complex 1 features a 3D threefold interpenetrating dia array with a 4-connected 66 topol. Complex 2 shows a 1D helix chain structure connected by L1 ligands, which is finally extended into a rarely 2D 4L2 supramol. network via C-H···O hydrogen bond interactions. In addn., the luminescence and catalytic properties of the two complexes for the degrdn. of the methyl orange azo dye in a Fenton-like process were presented. The degrdn. efficiency of the methyl orange azo dye for 1 and 2 are 56% and 96%, resp.

      (a) Ferey, G.; Serre, C. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1380– 1399 DOI: 10.1039/b804302g
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40a
      Large breathing effects in three-dimensional porous hybrid matter: facts, analyses, rules and consequences
      Ferey, Gerard; Serre, Christian
      Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1380-1399CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. This crit. review focuses on a strange behavior of crystd. solid matter: its reversible swelling with large magnitude. This will be of interest for experts in porous solids but also for solid state chemists and physicists. Some examples, classified according to the dimensionality of the inorg. subnetwork, present the general requirements and the structural rules which govern the existence of this phenomenon. Its consequences concern specific applications related to sensors, energy savings, sustainable development and health (100 refs.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamu70%253D&md5=a620fc681f135bdce4044f16b18c60b1
      (b) Horike, S.; Shimomura, S.; Kitagawa, S. Nat. Chem. 2009, 1, 695– 704 DOI: 10.1038/nchem.444
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40b
      Soft porous crystals
      Horike, Satoshi; Shimomura, Satoru; Kitagawa, Susumu
      Nature Chemistry (2009), 1 (9), 695-704CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The field of host-guest complexation is intensely attractive from diverse perspectives, including materials science, chem. and biol. The uptake and encapsulation of guest species by host frameworks are being investigated for a wide variety of purposes, including sepn. and storage using zeolites, and recognition and sensing by enzymes in soln. Here we focus on the concept of the cooperative integration of 'softness' and 'regularity'. Recent developments on porous coordination polymers (or metal-org. frameworks) have provided the inherent properties that combine these features. Such soft porous crystals exhibit dynamic frameworks that are able to respond to external stimuli such as light, elec. fields or the presence of particular species, but they are also cryst. and can change their channels reversibly while retaining high regularity. We discuss the relationship between the structures and properties of these materials in view of their practical applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVGnt7vK&md5=c1f813fb0eef80c8a2456fc7f2a0c34c
    41. 41
      Cronan, C. S.; Walker, W. J.; Bloom, P. R. Nature 1986, 324, 140– 143 DOI: 10.1038/324140a0
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      41
      Predicting aqueous aluminum concentrations in natural waters
      Cronan, Christopher S.; Walker, William J.; Bloom, Paul R.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1986), 324 (6093), 140-3CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      A 2-component equil. model for predicting Al spatial and temporal variability in natural waters involves a solid-phase humic adsorbent and an Al(OH)3 mineral phase. Inputs for the model are soln. pH, Cu-extractable org. Al, and the titratable CO2H content of soil humus. This model will typically apply to surface org. horizons and peaty hydrol. source areas, whereas the inorg. soly. model will be appropriate for lower mineral soil horizons and for the groundwater zone.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2sXptV2j&md5=1692645f2e277298eed225c09e09de14
      (b) Nayak, P. Environ. Res. 2002, 89, 101– 115 DOI: 10.1006/enrs.2002.4352
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      41b
      Aluminum: Impacts and Disease
      Nayak, Prasunpriya
      Environmental Research (2002), 89 (2), 101-115CODEN: ENVRAL; ISSN:0013-9351. (Elsevier Science)
      A review. Al is the most widely distributed metal in the environment and is extensively used in modern daily life. Al enters into the body from the environment and from diet and medication. However, there is no known physiol. role for Al within the body and hence this metal may produce adverse physiol. effects. The impact of Al on neural tissues is well reported but studies on extraneural tissues are not well summarized. In this review, the impacts of Al on humans and its impact on major physiol. systems are summarized and discussed. The neuropathologies assocd. with high brain Al levels, including structural, biochem., and neurobehavioral changes, were summarized. In addn., the impact of Al on the musculoskeletal system, respiratory system, cardiovascular system, hepatobiliary system, endocrine system, urinary system, and reproductive system are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Highly selective detection of phosphate in very complicated matrixes with an off-on fluorescent probe of europium-adjusted carbon dots
      Zhao, Heng-Xin; Liu, Li-Qin; Liu, Zhong-De; Wang, Yi; Zhao, Xi-Juan; Huang, Cheng-Zhi
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (9), 2604-2606CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A simple method for phosphate (Pi) detection is established by developing an off-on fluorescence probe of europium-adjusted carbon dots (CDs), which has been successfully applied to the detection of Pi in very complicated matrixes such as artificial wetlands system.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXitVCmsb4%253D&md5=0894630041ffae10a158432c03be1492

      Kessler, M. A. Anal. Chem. 1999, 71, 1540– 1543 DOI: 10.1021/ac971313o
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      43
      Probing the Dissociation State of Acid-Base Indicators by Time-Resolved Lanthanide Luminescence: A Convenient Transduction Scheme for Optical Chemical Sensors
      Kessler, Manfred A.
      Analytical Chemistry (1999), 71 (8), 1540-1543CODEN: ANCHAM; ISSN:0003-2700. (American Chemical Society)
      The paper describes a new method for the optical measurement of pH based on time-resolved luminescence. The intense line emission of a europium terpyridine chelate is strongly quenched by bromothymol blue (BTB). Since only the blue base form acts as a quencher, the decay time of the luminescence directly reflects the protonation state of BTB and, hence, the pH of the soln. The exptl. results are in good agreement with a theor. model that accommodates both the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation and the Stern-Volmer law. Decay time-based response curves have the same sigmoidal shape as conventional titrn. curves, but their apparent pKa is shifted to lower pH, depending on the total concn. of BTB used. All luminescence decay curves featured single-exponential decay. With 8 μmol/L BTB, decay times decreased from 1172 μs at pH 2.60 to 120 μs at pH 8.94, and the apparent pKa shifted from 7.0 to 6.1. A Stern-Volmer quenching const. of 9.55 × 105 was obtained for the base form of BTB. The method appears particularly useful as a transduction scheme for optical chem. sensors, since it makes conventional indicator dyes available to decay time-based sensing.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXhvVeisro%253D&md5=d53c9f95ff6a8662e8f35f7773f3baee
    44. 44
      (a) Razek, T.; Spear, S.; Hassan, S. S. M.; Arnold, M. A. Talanta 1999, 48, 269– 275 DOI: 10.1016/S0039-9140(98)00245-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44a
      Selective measurement of chromium(VI) by fluorescence quenching of ruthenium
      Razek, Taha M. A.; Spear, Scott; Hassan, Saad S. M.; Arnold, Mark A.
      Talanta (1999), 48 (2), 269-275CODEN: TLNTA2; ISSN:0039-9140. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A flow injection method is described for the selective measurement of Cr(VI) in aq. solns. This method is based on the dynamic quenching of Ru(II) fluorescence. The detection limit is 0.43 ppm and 40 samples can be analyzed per h. Selectivity is demonstrated over ferrous, Ni, cupric and Zn cations and no effect is obsd. from sulfate, chloride, borate and phosphate. Some interference quenching was measured for cyanide and nitrate, but the method is more responsive to Cr(VI) by factors of 10.2 and 82, resp. The effects of soln. pH, carrier stream flow rate and Ru concn. are demonstrated. Results indicate the method is suitable for measuring Cr(VI) in effluents from electroplating baths.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXpsVymug%253D%253D&md5=919f73d2ee90a53beed14654db8f8c49
      (b) Hassan, S. S. M.; Abdel-Shafi, A. A.; Mohammed, A. H. K. Talanta 2005, 67, 696– 702 DOI: 10.1016/j.talanta.2005.03.019
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44b
      Flow injection fluorometric determination of chromium(VI) in electroplating baths by luminescence quenching of tris(2,2'-bipyridyl)ruthenium(II)
      Hassan, Saad S. M.; Abdel-Shafi, Ayman A.; Mohammed, Ayman H. K.
      Talanta (2005), 67 (4), 696-702CODEN: TLNTA2; ISSN:0039-9140. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A sensitive and selective luminescence quenching method is developed and used for manual and flow injection anal. (FIA) of Cr(VI) by reaction with [Ru(bpy)3]2+. The emission peak of Ru(II) at 595 nm is linearly decreased as a function of Cr(VI) concn. This permits detn. of Cr(VI) ion over the concn. range 0.1-20 μg ml-1 with a detection limit of 33 ng ml-1. The quenching process is due to an electron transfer from the luminescent [Ru(bpy)3]2+ complex ion to Cr(VI) giving the nonluminescent [Ru(bpy)3]3+ complex ion. Selectivity for Cr(VI) over many anions and transition, alkali and alk. earth metal cations is demonstrated. High concn. levels of sulfate, chloride, borate, acetate, phosphate, nitrate, cyanide, Pb2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ni2+ and Mn2+ ions are tolerated. The effects of soln. pH and [Ru(bpy)3]2+ reagent concn. were examd. and the reaction conditions are optimized. Validation of the method according to the quality assurance stds. show suitability of the proposed method for use in the quality control assessment of Cr(VI) in complex matrixes without prior treatment. The method is successfully applied to det. Cr(VI) in electroplating baths using flow injection anal. Results with a mean std. deviation of ±0.6% were obtained which compare fairly well with data obtained using at. absorption spectrometry.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXpsFylu7Y%253D&md5=d06f4ed5489014c015db60d3a485bb71
    45. 45
      Shi, P. F.; Hu, H. C.; Zhang, Z. Y.; Xiong, G.; Zhao, B. Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 3985– 3988 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC09081K
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      Heterometal-organic frameworks as highly sensitive and highly selective luminescent probes to detect I- ions in aqueous solutions
      Shi, Peng-Fei; Hu, Huan-Cheng; Zhang, Zhan-Yun; Xiong, Gang; Zhao, Bin
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (19), 3985-3988CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two cationic heterometal-org. frameworks (Eu-Zn (1·NO3-) and Tb-Zn (2·NO3-)) with NO3- counter-anions in the channels are structurally and luminously characterized. Both of them can serve as highly sensitive and highly selective luminescent probes for detecting I- ions in aq. solns. In particular, 2·NO3- can selectively and reversibly detect I- with a fast response time of just 10 s and an extremely low detection limit of 0.001 ppm. Mechanism studies reveal that I- is quickly oxidized to form I3- with the help of 1·NO3- or 2·NO3-, leading to luminescence quenching. This represents the first report of MOF-based luminescent probes for the detection of I- in aq. solns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlsFyitA%253D%253D&md5=6e68990880d9cd5fca58d610e3530ffe
    46. 46
      (a) Jiang, H. L.; Feng, D.; Wang, K.; Gu, Z. Y.; Wei, Z.; Chen, Y. P.; Zhou, H. C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 13934– 13938 DOI: 10.1021/ja406844r
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46a
      An Exceptionally Stable, Porphyrinic Zr Metal-Organic Framework Exhibiting pH-Dependent Fluorescence
      Jiang, Hai-Long; Feng, Dawei; Wang, Kecheng; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Wei, Zhangwen; Chen, Ying-Pin; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (37), 13934-13938CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A reaction between a ZrIV salt and a porphyrinic tetracarboxylic acid leads to a metal-org. framework (MOF) with two types of open channels, representing a MOF featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The MOF is formulated as Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(OH)4(H2O)4(H2TCPP)2 (denoted as PCN-225) and it's Zn-contg. deriv. is denoted as PCN-225(Zn). The MOFs remains intact in both boiling H2O and aq. solns. with pH ranging from 1 to 11, a remarkably extensive pH range that a MOF can sustain. Given its exceptional stability and pH-dependent fluorescent intensity, the MOF can potentially be applied in fluorescent pH sensing.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlChtLzI&md5=e5a2d00475d89e88c8be9d15d63dd4e7
      (b) Wang, J. Q.; Huang, L.; Xue, M.; Wang, Y.; Gao, L.; Zhu, J. H.; Zou, Z. J. Phys. Chem. C 2008, 112, 5014– 5022 DOI: 10.1021/jp7099948
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46b
      Architecture of a Hybrid Mesoporous Chemosensor for Fe3+ by Covalent Coupling Bis-Schiff Base PMBA onto the CPTES-Functionalized SBA-15
      Wang, Jian-Qiang; Huang, Li; Xue, Min; Wang, Ying; Gao, Ling; Zhu, Jian Hua; Zou, Zhigang
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2008), 112 (13), 5014-5022CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel hybrid mesoporous material PMBA-SBA was designed and synthesized by immobilizing bis-Schiff base N,N'-(1,4-phenylenedimethyli- dyne)bis(1,4-benzenediamine) (PMBA) within the channels of (γ-chloropropyl)triethoxysilane (CPTES) modified SBA-15. TEM images of the hybrid materials illustrated the reservation of the hexagonal ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15 after functionalization. The characteristic absorbance of the C:N stretching vibration of the Schiff base was obsd. in the IR spectrum of the hybrid materials, indicating the successful immobilization of PMBA in the mesoporous composite, while the XPS spectra confirmed that the linkage of the PMBA mol. within the channels of CPTES-functionalized SBA-15 is realized by forming a covalent bond between amino and chloropropyl groups. This novel mesoporous material PMBA-SBA showed a high selectivity to Fe3+ ion, which results from a dramatic fluorescence quenching by the addn. of Fe3+ ion upon the suspensions of PMBA-SBA. A good linearity between the fluorescence intensity of PMBA-SBA and the concn. of Fe3+ ion is constructed, which enables this hybrid martial as a fluorescence chemosensor for detecting the Fe3+ ion with a satisfactory detection limit of 1.98 × 10-6 M. Judged on the linear equation, the fluorescence quenching of the hybrid material by Fe3+ ion progresses by static quenching forming a non-fluorescence complex.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXivV2ns74%253D&md5=7c8677db744387ed3fc5f982b2ceae8a
      (c) Lu, Z. Z.; Zhang, R.; Li, Y. Z.; Guo, Z. J.; Zheng, H. G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 4172– 4174 DOI: 10.1021/ja109437d
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46c
      Solvatochromic Behavior of a Nanotubular Metal-Organic Framework for Sensing Small Molecules
      Lu, Zhen-Zhong; Zhang, Rui; Li, Yi-Zhi; Guo, Zi-Jian; Zheng, He-Gen
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4172-4174CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A nanotubular metal-org. framework (MOF), {[(WS4Cu4)I2(dptz)3]·DMF}n (dptz = 3,6-di(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, DMF = DMF) for sensing small solvent mols. is presented. When accommodating different solvent mols. as guests, the resulting inclusion compds. exhibit different colors depending on the solvent guests, and more interestingly, the band gaps of these solvent-included complexes are in linear correlation with the polarity of the guest solvents. The solvent mols. can be sensed by the changes of UV-visible spectra of the corresponding inclusion compds., showing a new way of signal transduction as a new kind of sensor. The sensing by such a MOF occurs within the channel-contg. material rather than on the external surface.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      1. 1
        (a) Venkataraman, D.; Lee, S.; Moore, J. S.; Zhang, P.; Hirsch, K. A.; Gardner, G. B.; Covey, A. C.; Prentice, C. L. Chem. Mater. 1996, 8, 2030– 2014 DOI: 10.1021/cm950594i
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1a
        Coordination Networks Based on Multitopic Ligands and Silver(I) Salts: A Study of Network Connectivity and Topology as a Function of Counterion
        Venkataraman, D.; Lee, Stephen; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Zhang, Peng; Hirsch, Keith A.; Gardner, Geoffrey B.; Covey, Aaron C.; Prentice, Christine L.
        Chemistry of Materials (1996), 8 (8), 2030-2040CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Much like hydrogen bonding, Ag-N coordination bonds can be reliably used for the construction of supramol. networks. From a solid-state structural study of silver(I) complexes of multitopic ligands, the authors describe coordination networks formed in the presence of the weakly coordinating triflate (CF3SO3-) counterion and the noncoordinating hexafluorophosphate (PF6-) species. For complexes prepd. with silver(I) triflate, counterion coordination is characteristic. Also, for the triflate complexes presented, ditopic ligands form 1-dimensional, chainlike structures and tritopic ligands form 3-connected nets. A tetratopic ligand also forms a 3-connected net due to the triflate-capped silver(I) coordination. In contrast, more varied network topol. is seen in complexes of ditopic ligands prepd. with silver(I) hexafluorophosphate.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XksFaiurc%253D&md5=1bdd5b2a558d53222a02de0b46c57602
        (b) Yaghi, O. M.; Pinnavaia, T. J.; Thorpe, M. F., Eds. In Access in Nanoporous Materials; Plenum: New York, 1995; p 111.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (c) Stein, A.; Keller, S. W.; Mallouk, T. E. Science 1993, 259, 1558– 1564 DOI: 10.1126/science.259.5101.1558
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1c
        Turning down the heat: design and mechanism in solid-state synthesis
        Stein, Andreas; Keller, Steven W.; Mallouk, Thomas E.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1993), 259 (5101), 1558-64CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        A review with >43 refs. Solid-state compds. historically were prepd. through high-temp. solid-solid reactions. New mechanistic understanding of these reactions suggests possible routes to metastable compns. and structures and to thermodynamically stable, low-temp. phases that decomp. at higher temps. Intermediate-temp. synthetic techniques, including flux and hydrothermal methods, and low-temp. intercalation and coordination reactions, recently were developed and were used to prep. unprecedented materials with interesting electronic, optical, and catalytic properties. The trend in modern solid-state synthesis resembles increasingly the approach used in small-mol. chem., in the sense that attention to reaction mechanism and the use of mol. building blocks result in an ability to prep. materials of designed structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXitVertbc%253D&md5=9cef68a198dffe7f22a6bb26908e240f
        (d) Fagan, P. J.; Ward, M. D. Sci. Am. 1992, 267, 48– 54 DOI: 10.1038/scientificamerican0792-48
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1d
        Building molecular crystals
        Fagan, Paul J.; Ward, Michael D.
        Scientific American (1992), 267 (1), 48-54CODEN: SCAMAC; ISSN:0036-8733.
        A discussion with refs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xlt1WktLo%253D&md5=ec9c1e82393b1d07d6f7b6c122949591
        (e) Bein, T. Supramolecular Architecture: Synthetic Control in Thin Films and Solids; American Chemical Society: Washington, DC, 1992.
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (g) Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1990, 112, 1546– 1554 DOI: 10.1021/ja00160a038
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1g
        Design and construction of a new class of scaffolding-like materials comprising infinite polymeric frameworks of 3D-linked molecular rods. A reappraisal of the zinc cyanide and cadmium cyanide structures and the synthesis and structure of the diamond-related frameworks [N(CH3)4][CuIZnII(CN)4] and CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4.xC6H5NO2
        Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, Richard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1990), 112 (4), 1546-54CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        It is proposed that a new and potentially extensive class of scaffolding-like materials may be afforded by linking together centers with either a tetrahedral or an octahedral array of valences by rodlike connecting units. Some simple general principles concerning the design and construction of these frameworks are presented together with reasons for expecting them to show unusual and useful properties. Two of the simplest conceivable systems of this type are isomorphous Zn(CN)2 and Cd(CN)2 whose structures were reexamd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, confirming the earlier description based on powder diffraction data of 2 interpenetrating diamond-related frameworks: cubic, space group P‾43m, Z = 2; with a 5.9002(9) Å (Zn(CN)2) and 6.301(1) Å (Cd(CN)2); 2 unique metal centers, 1 surrounded tetrahedrally by 4C and the other by 4N donors; MCNM rods linear; Zn-C 1.923(6), Zn-N 2.037(5), Cd-C 2.099(5), Cd-N 2.196(4), C-N 1.150(5) Å in Zn(CN)2, and 1.162(5) Å in Cd(CN)2. The interpenetration of sep. frameworks demonstrated in these archetypal structures is likely to be a major concern in future studies of more complex scaffolding materials. [N(CH3)4][CuZn(CN)4] was deliberately designed to demonstrate one conceivable way of preventing interpenetration; it is cubic, space group F‾43m, with A 11.609(3) Å; Z = 4. The structure contains a single diamond-related framework with alternating tetrahedral Cu(I) and Zn(II) centers and linear rods that are very likely of the type CuCNZn with bond distances Cu-C 1.877(8) and Zn-N 2.069(15) Å, Z(CH3)4+ ions occupy half the adamantane cavities generated by the framework, the remaining cavities being vacant. CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4·xC6H5NO2 (x ≥ 7.7) represents the first attempt to generate an infinite 3-dimensional framework with rods of some complexity. It is tetragonal, space group I‾4m2, with a 13.620(2) and c 22.642(2) Å; Z = 2. The structure contains a diamond-related cationic framework with C·C6H4·CN·Cu rods of length 8.856(2) Å. The framework is tetragonally elongated along the c axis apparently as a result of nonbonded interactions between the 8 ortho-H atoms around the methane C centers. There is no interpenetration. The framework generates very large adamantane-like cavities occupied by disordered C6H5NO2 (at least 7.7 mols. per Cu) together with BF4- ions. The crystals undergo ready anion exchange. The material is unusual in that approx. two thirds by vol. of what is undoubtedly a crystal is effectively liq. The results provide confidence that a wide range of scaffolding-like solids should prove accessible.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXovVOjtw%253D%253D&md5=2a9efabcd93072e8668a50199c51320c
        (h) Lu, J.; Harrison, W. T. A.; Jacobson, A. J. Angew. Chem. 1995, 107, 2759– 2760 DOI: 10.1002/ange.19951072231
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (i) Lu, J.; Harrison, W. T. A.; Jacobson, A. J. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl. 1995, 34, 2557– 2559 DOI: 10.1002/anie.199525571
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1i
        Synthesis and structure of three-dimensional coordination polymers [(Me3Sn)4M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W)
        Lu, J.; Harrison, W. T. A.; Jacobson, A. J.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English (1995), 34 (22), 2557-9CODEN: ACIEAY; ISSN:0570-0833. (VCH)
        Reaction of K4M(CN)8 (M = Mo, W) with Me3SnCl in H2O/THF gave title compds., [(Me3Sn)4M(CN)8] (M = Mo, W). The crystal structures of THF solvates of both the compds. were detd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXpslOmsL0%253D&md5=589dd0923292dacf71a4464dc3eaa2b3
      2. 2
        (a) Moulton, B.; Zaworotko, M. J. Chem. Rev. 2001, 101, 1629– 1658 DOI: 10.1021/cr9900432
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2a
        From molecules to crystal engineering. Supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism in network solids
        Moulton, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2001), 101 (6), 1629-1658CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with 299 refs. on how the advances in supramol. chem. have impacted the manner in which chemists view the existence of single crystals and the design of new cryst. phases. Coordination polymers, H-bonded networks, and supramol. isomerism and polymorphism are considered.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjtlyqtrg%253D&md5=00fbfe863055d07d1773be77dc52f023
        (b) Yaghi, O. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Ockwig, N. W.; Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J. Nature 2003, 423, 705– 714 DOI: 10.1038/nature01650
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2b
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea
        (c) Kitagawa, S.; Kitaura, R.; Noro, S.-i. Angew. Chem. 2004, 116, 2388– 2430 DOI: 10.1002/ange.200300610
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (d) Kitagawa, S.; Kitaura, R.; Noro, S. I. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 2334– 2375 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200300610
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2d
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktFShtLk%253D&md5=9df52e99bad3cc0db67f65551a8c154f
        (e) Kubas, G. Chem. Rev. 2007, 107, 4152– 4205 DOI: 10.1021/cr050197j
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2e
        Fundamentals of H2 Binding and Reactivity on Transition Metals Underlying Hydrogenase Function and H2 Production and Storage
        Kubas, Gregory J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 107 (10), 4152-4205CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Focal points of this review are how activation of H2 occurs on metal complexes and on enzymes in nature such as hydrogenases, and the relevance to new materials for hydrogen storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFehu7rJ&md5=88bc94ddb04ff0d00ddabf910710f2fe
      3. 3
        (a) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469– 472 DOI: 10.1126/science.1067208
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3a
        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
        (b) Bourrelly, S.; Llewellyn, P.; Serre, C.; Millange, F.; Loiseau, T.; Férey, G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 13519– 13521 DOI: 10.1021/ja054668v
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        Different Adsorption Behaviors of Methane and Carbon Dioxide in the Isotypic Nanoporous Metal Terephthalates MIL-53 and MIL-47
        Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Serre, Christian; Millange, Franck; Loiseau, Thierry; Ferey, Gerard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (39), 13519-13521CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A distinct step in the isotherm occurs during the adsorption of CO2 on MIL-53 at 304 K. Such behavior is neither obsd. during the adsorption of CH4 on MIL-53 nor during the adsorption on the isostructural MIL-47. This phenomenon seems to be due to a different mechanism than that of previous adsorption steps on MOF samples. It is suggested that a breathing behavior is induced in MIL-53 during CO2 adsorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXpvFSnu70%253D&md5=e3d0228e57af031b6019deeeffa6d575
        (c) Panella, B.; Hirscher, M.; Puetter, H.; Mueller, U. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2006, 16, 520– 524 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.200500561
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        Hydrogen adsorption in metal-organic frameworks: Cu-MOFs and Zn-MOFs compared
        Panella, Barbara; Hirscher, Michael; Puetter, Hermann; Mueller, Ulrich
        Advanced Functional Materials (2006), 16 (4), 520-524CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Hydrogen adsorption in 2 different metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), MOF-5 and Cu-BTC (BTC: benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate), with Zn2+ and Cu2+ as central metal ions, resp., is studied at temps. ranging from 77 K to room temp. The process responsible for hydrogen storage in these MOFs is pure phys. adsorption with a heat of adsorption of ∼-4 kJ mol-1. With a satn. value of 5.1 wt.-% for the hydrogen uptake at high pressures and 77 K, MOF-5 shows the highest storage capacity ever reported for cryst. microporous materials. However, at low pressures Cu-BTC shows a higher hydrogen uptake than MOF-5, making Cu-based MOFs more promising candidates for potential storage materials. Also, the hydrogen uptake is correlated with the sp. surface area for cryst. microporous materials, as shown for MOFs and zeolites.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XislSkur0%253D&md5=ce54854e10395053338447edcfcbdbe4
        (d) Liu, Y.; Eubank, J. F.; Cairns, A. J.; Eckert, J.; Kravtsov, V. C.; Luebke, R.; Eddaoudi, M. Angew. Chem. 2007, 119, 3342– 3345 DOI: 10.1002/ange.200604306
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (e) Liu, Y.; Eubank, J. F.; Cairns, A. J.; Eckert, J.; Kravtsov, V. C.; Luebke, R.; Eddaoudi, M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 3278– 3283 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200604306
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3e
        Assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on indium-trimer building blocks: a porous MOF with soc topology and high hydrogen storage
        Liu, Yunling; Eubank, Jarrod F.; Cairns, Amy J.; Eckert, Juergen; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; Luebke, Ryan; Eddaoudi, Mohamed
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (18), 3278-3283CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The synthesis and structure of two MOFs based on oxo-bridged trinuclear indium carboxylate clusters are reported. The one MOF has a cubic structure with a CaB6 topol. and the other with an unprecedented soc topol. (soc = square-octahedron). The results obtained indicate that MOFs possessing the characteristics of these two MOFs, combined with the modularity of their construction which allows higher surface areas to be obtained, will permit the attainment of the US DOE target for H2 uptake.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXlsVKhs7k%253D&md5=25cc409adc0903fb26719f96861d8b70
        (f) Phan, A.; Doonan, C. J.; Uribe-Romo, F. J.; Knobler, C. B.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2010, 43, 58– 67 DOI: 10.1021/ar900116g
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3f
        Synthesis, Structure, and Carbon Dioxide Capture Properties of Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks
        Phan, Anh; Doonan, Christian J.; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Knobler, Carolyn B.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2010), 43 (1), 58-67CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review concerning the synthesis, structure, and CO2 properties of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF) is given. A major goal in zeolite chem. is to create a structure in which metal ions and functionalizable org. units comprise an integral portion of the framework, and by virtue of the flexibility with which metal ions and org. moieties can be varied, is a key to further improve zeolite properties and access new applications. Within the last 5 years >90 new ZIF structures have been reported. It is possible to synthesize ZIF with topologies previously unknown in zeolites and to mimic known structures. Topic discussed include: synthesis and general structure; ZIF structures and the zeolite problem; ZIF structural complexity; applications for sepn. and selective capture of CO2; and perspectives and outlook.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlegu77O&md5=de5a9f235d52e2ce66778e7e7c187e37
      4. 4
        (a) Deng, H.; Doonan, C. J.; Furukawa, H.; Ferreira, R. B.; Towne, J.; Knobler, C. B.; Wang, B.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2010, 327, 846– 850 DOI: 10.1126/science.1181761
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4a
        Multiple Functional Groups of Varying Ratios in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Deng, Hexiang; Doonan, Christian J.; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Ferreira, Ricardo B.; Towne, John; Knobler, Carolyn B.; Wang, Bo; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 327 (5967), 846-850CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) can incorporate a large no. of different functionalities on linking groups in a way that mixes the linker, rather than forming sep. domains. The authors made complex MOFs from 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (denoted by A in this work) and its derivs. -NH2, -Br, -(Cl)2, -NO2, -Me2, -C4H4, -(OC3H5)2, and -(OC7H7)2 (denoted by B to I,, resp.) to synthesize 18 multivariate (MTV) MOF-5 type structures that contain up to eight distinct functionalities in one phase. The backbone (Zn oxide and phenylene units) of these structures is ordered, but the distribution of functional groups is disordered. The complex arrangements of several functional groups within the pores can lead to properties that are not simply linear sums of those of the pure components. For example, a member of this series, MTV-MOF-5-EHI, exhibits up to 400% better selectivity for CO2 over CO compared with its best same-link counterparts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhslWju7o%253D&md5=40f9720d9a7633e6102cab3256be0468
        (b) Wang, X.; Liu, L.; Jacobson, A. J. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45, 6499– 6503 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200602556
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4b
        Intercalation of organic molecules into vanadium(IV) benzenedicarboxylate: adsorbate structure and selective absorption of organosulfur compounds
        Wang, Xiqu; Liu, Lumei; Jacobson, Allan J.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (39), 6499-6503CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The guest acid mols. of hydrothermally synthesized [V(O)(bdc)](H2bdc)0.71 (bdc = benzenedicarboxylate) are removed to give high-quality single crystals of [V(O)(bdc)]. On adsorption of guest mols. from liq. phase, it undergoes crystal-to-crystal transformation. Furthermore, it also selectively adsorbs thiophene and di-Me sulfide from methane.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtFWgsrvL&md5=bf283b30c5374daba100602acfed8c54
        (c) Alaerts, L.; Maes, M.; Giebeler, L.; Jacobs, P. A.; Martens, J. A.; Denayer, J. F. M.; Kirschhock, C. E. A.; De Vos, D. E. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 14170– 14178 DOI: 10.1021/ja802761z
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4c
        Selective Adsorption and Separation of ortho-Substituted Alkylaromatics with the Microporous Aluminum Terephthalate MIL-53
        Alaerts, Luc; Maes, Michael; Giebeler, Lars; Jacobs, Pierre A.; Martens, Johan A.; Denayer, Joeri F. M.; Kirschhock, Christine E. A.; De Vos, Dirk E.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (43), 14170-14178CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The metal-org. framework MIL-53(Al) was tested for selective adsorption and sepn. of xylenes and ethylbenzene, ethyltoluenes, and cymenes using batch, pulse chromatog., and breakthrough expts. In all conditions tested, MIL-53 has the largest affinity for the ortho-isomer among each group of alkylarom. compds. Sepns. of the ortho-compds. from the other isomers can be realized using a column packed with MIL-53 crystallites. As evidenced by Rietveld refinements, specific interactions of the xylenes with the pore walls of MIL-53 det. selectivity. In comparison with the structurally similar metal-org. framework MIL-47, the selectivities among alkylaroms. found for MIL-53 are different. Sepn. of ethyltoluene and cymene isomers is more effective on MIL-53 than on MIL-47; the pores of MIL-53 seem to be a more suitable environment for hosting the larger ethyltoluene and cymene isomers than those of MIL-47.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtF2lsrjI&md5=fa435229a0a96bed1f933ac5d00993eb
        (d) Cychosz, K. A.; Wong-Foy, A. G.; Matzger, A. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 6938– 6939 DOI: 10.1021/ja802121u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4d
        Liquid Phase Adsorption by Microporous Coordination Polymers: Removal of Organosulfur Compounds
        Cychosz, Katie A.; Wong-Foy, Antek G.; Matzger, Adam J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (22), 6938-6939CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The utility of microporous coordination polymers (MCPs) for the adsorption of large organosulfur compds. (benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene, 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene) found in fuels is demonstrated. Large capacities are obtained at both low and high sulfur concns. For 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene, the compd. most difficult to remove using current industrial techniques, a capacity of 41 g S/kg MCP at 1500 ppmw S is achieved by UMCM-150. The size/shape of the pores in the MCP, rather than the surface area or pore vol., is the most important factor controlling adsorption capacity.

        4f
        Selective adsorption and separation of xylene isomers and ethylbenzene with the microporous vanadium(IV) terephthalate MIL-47
        Alaerts, Luc; Kirshhock, Christine E. A.; Maes, Michael; van der Veen, Monique A.; Finsy, Vincent; Depla, Anouschka; Martens, Johan A.; Baron, Gino V.; Jacobs, Pierre A.; Denayer, Joeri F. M.; De Vos, Dirk E.

        The microporous metal-org. framework MIL-47 is an excellent adsorbent for the sepn. of C8 alkylarom. compds., such as ethylbenzene, meta-xylene, and para-xylene. The potential of MIL-47, with its high uptake capacity and its hydrophobic nature, for real sepns. of the C8 alkylarom. compds. was demonstrated by breakthrough and chromatog. expts.

        5a
        A fluorescent metal-organic framework for highly selective detection of nitro explosives in the aqueous phase
        Nagarkar, Sanjog S.; Desai, Aamod V.; Ghosh, Sujit K.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (64), 8915-8918CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Selective and sensitive nitro explosive detection by a porous fluorescent metal-org. framework has been reported. For the first time MOF based selective explosive detection in the presence of other nitro analytes in aq. media is demonstrated. The fluorescent MOF (Uio-67@N) has the mol. formula Zr6O4(OH)4(L)6, in which L is derived from 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)-3-pyridinecarboxylic acid. Uio-67@N has a high sensitivity for detection of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol, even in the presence of other nitro explosives.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtVOnsr3N&md5=b65653e41708fd8dd42bf9fafb40cbcf

        5b
        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks for chemical sensing and explosive detection
        Hu, Zhichao; Deibert, Benjamin J.; Li, Jing
        Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5815-5840CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a unique class of cryst. solids comprised of metal cations (or metal clusters) and org. ligands that have shown promise for a wide variety of applications. Over the past 15 years, research and development of these materials have become one of the most intensely and extensively pursued areas. A very interesting and well-investigated topic is their optical emission properties and related applications. Several reviews have provided a comprehensive overview covering many aspects of the subject up to 2011. This review intends to provide an update of work published since then and focuses on the photoluminescence (PL) properties of MOFs and their possible utility in chem. and biol. sensing and detection. The spectrum of this review includes the origin of luminescence in MOFs, the advantages of luminescent MOF (LMOF) based sensors, general strategies in designing sensory materials, and examples of various applications in sensing and detection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Slu7nL&md5=0369c383e7a6f4eeb65c73b2b66f1137
        (c) Kim, T. K.; Lee, J. H.; Moon, D.; Moon, H. R. Inorg. Chem. 2013, 52, 589– 595 DOI: 10.1021/ic3011458
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5c
        Luminescent Li-Based Metal-Organic Framework Tailored for the Selective Detection of Explosive Nitroaromatic Compounds: Direct Observation of Interaction Sites
        Kim, Tae Kyung; Lee, Jae Hwa; Moon, Dohyun; Moon, Hoi Ri
        Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (2), 589-595CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A luminescent lithium metal-org. framework (MOF), {Li3[Li(DMF)2](CPMA)2}·4DMF·H2O, is constructed from the solvothermal reaction of Li+ and a well-designed org. ligand, bis(4-carboxyphenyl)-N-methylamine (H2CPMA). A Li-based MOF can detect an explosive arom. compd. contg. nitro groups as an explosophore, by showing a dramatic color change with concurrent luminescence quenching in the solid state. The detection sites are proven directly through single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations, which show strong interactions between the arom. rings of the electron-rich CPMA2- mols. and the electron-deficient nitrobenzene.

        An intense visible yellow-orange emission with long lifetime and enhanced quantum yield was achieved for a metal-org. framework based on a highly light-harvesting dicyclometalated Ir(III) unit, which shows effective detection of nitroarom. explosives on the ppm scale. Crystallog. data are given.

        (a) Kole, G. K.; Vittal, J. J. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2013, 42, 1755– 1775 DOI: 10.1039/C2CS35234F

        6a
        Solid-state reactivity and structural transformations involving coordination polymers
        Kole, Goutam Kumar; Vittal, Jagadese J.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2013), 42 (4), 1755-1775CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This tutorial review discusses recent literature on coordination polymers and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that exhibit solid-state reactivity and structural transformation under various exptl. conditions. Removal or exchange of solvents and guest mols., exposure to reactive vapors, and external stimuli such as heat, light or mechanochem. force cause such structural transformations and these are often manifested by various phys. properties such as color, magnetism, luminescence, chirality, porosity, etc. due to change in coordination no. and geometry, dimensionality, interpenetration, etc. More drastic transformations related to the exchange of metal ions, pillar ligands and insertion of addnl. ligands between the layers also were demonstrated. The vast area of dynamic behavior of coordination polymers and their stimuli-responsive properties also were addressed briefly.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsV2kuro%253D&md5=91fae4fb685a46e2a6fd3a76b3891515
        (b) Sun, C.-Y.; Wang, X.-L.; Qin, C.; Jin, J.-L.; Su, Z.-M.; Huang, P.; Shao, K.-Z. Chem. - Eur. J. 2013, 19, 3639– 3645 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201203080
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6b
        Solvatochromic Behavior of Chiral Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks and Their Applications for Sensing Small Molecules and Separating Cationic Dyes
        Sun, Chun-Yi; Wang, Xin-Long; Qin, Chao; Jin, Jun-Ling; Su, Zhong-Min; Huang, Peng; Shao, Kui-Zhan
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (11), 3639-3645CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two anionic metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with 1-dimensional mesoporous tubes (1) and chiral mesoporous cages (2) were rationally constructed by a predesigned size-extended hexatopic ligand, namely, 5,5',5''-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tris(azanediyl)triisophthalate (TATAT). Charge neutrality is achieved by protonated dimethylamine cations. Notably, the two MOFs can be used to sep. large mols. based on ionic selectivity rather than the size-exclusion effect so far reported in the literature. Owing to the imino triazine backbone and carboxyl groups of the hexatopic ligand, which provide important host-guest interactions, rare solvatochromic phenomena of 1 and 2 are obsd. on incorporating acetone and ethanol guests. Also, guest-dependent luminescence properties of compd. 2 were studied, and luminescence intensity is significantly enhanced in toluene and benzene, while quenching effects are obsd. in acetone and ethanol. Thus, compd. 2 may be a potential material for luminescent probes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslWrsrY%253D&md5=e77d279486094c6fd54ea869fce702cf
        (c) Yi, F.-Y.; Yang, W.; Sun, Z.-M. J. Mater. Chem. 2012, 22, 23201– 23209 DOI: 10.1039/c2jm35273g
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6c
        Highly selective acetone fluorescent sensors based on microporous Cd(II) metal-organic frameworks
        Yi, Fei-Yan; Yang, Weiting; Sun, Zhong-Ming
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2012), 22 (43), 23201-23209CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Solvothermal reaction of Cd2+ ions and a hexavalent carboxylic acid (H6L, I) afforded a Cd(II) metal org. framework (Cd-MOF), {[Cd3(L)(H2O)2(DMF)2]·5DMF}n (1). Its structure consists of trinuclear CdII building units, which are further bridged by the carboxylic ligand, resulting in a 4,4-connected topol. net (sra). By introducing a rigid N-donor ligand 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (dib), a new Cd-MOF (2) {[Cd3(L)(dib)]·3H2O·5DMA}n was isolated, in which the coordinated sites of solvent mols. in 1 were completely replaced by dib. The resulting trinuclear Cd3 subunits are further bridged into a 2-fold interpenetrating network with DMA and water mols. located in the void space. The luminescent properties of the two microporous Cd-MOFs dispersed in different solvents were studied systematically, demonstrating unique selectivity for the detection of acetone via a fluorescence quenching mechanism. Their luminescence intensities decreased to 50% at an acetone content of 0.3 vol.% and were almost completely quenched at a concn. of 1.0 vol.%, thus, they can be considered as excellent potential luminescent probes for the detection of acetone.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsFSqtLzK&md5=746de7d9b2dd374e83b5160035ad19e1
        (d) Chen, B. L.; Xiang, S. C.; Qian, G. D. Acc. Chem. Res. 2010, 43, 1115– 1124 DOI: 10.1021/ar100023y
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6d
        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Functional Pores for Recognition of Small Molecules
        Chen, Banglin; Xiang, Shengchang; Qian, Guodong
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2010), 43 (8), 1115-1124CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Mol. recognition, an important process in biol. and chem. systems, governs the diverse functions of a variety of enzymes and unique properties of some synthetic receptors. Because mol. recognition is based on weak interactions between receptors and substrates, the design and assembly of synthetic receptors to mimic biol. systems and the development of novel materials to discriminate different substrates for selective recognition of specific mols. has proved challenging. The extensive research on synthetic receptors for mol. recognition, particularly on noncovalent complexes self-assembled by hydrogen bonding and metal-org. coordination, has revealed some underlying principles. In particular, these studies have demonstrated that the shapes of the supramol. receptors play significant roles in their specific and selective recognition of substrates: receptors can offer concave surfaces that complement their convex targets. This Account describes our research to develop a synthetic mol. recognition platform using porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). These materials contain functional pores to direct their specific and unique recognition of small mols. through several types of interactions: van der Waals interactions of the framework surface with the substrate, metal-substrate interactions, and hydrogen bonding of the framework surface with the substrate. These materials have potential applications for gas storage, sepn., and sensing. We demonstrate a simple strategy to construct a primitive cubic net of interpenetrated microporous MOFs from the self-assembly of the paddle-wheel clusters M2(CO2)4 (M = Cu2+, Zn2+, and Co2+) with two types of org. dicarboxylic acid and pillar bidentate linkers. This efficient method allows us to rationally tune the micropores to size-exclusively sort different small gas mols., leading to the highly selective sepn. and purifn. of gases. By optimizing the strong interactions between open metal sites within porous MOFs and gas mols. such as hydrogen and acetylene, we have developed several MOF materials with extraordinary acetylene storage capacity at room temp. We have also immobilized Lewis acidic and basic sites into luminescent porous MOFs to recognize and sense neutral and ionic species. Using the strategy to systematically immobilize different open metal sites within porous MOFs from the metallo-ligand precursors, we have developed the first microporous mixed-metal-org. framework (M'MOF) with enhanced affinity for hydrogen mols., which successfully sepd. D2 from H2 using kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving. Because we can functionalize the pores to direct their specific recognition of small mols., the emerging porous MOFs serve as novel functional materials for gas storage, sepn., heterogeneous catalysis, and sensing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlslyhtrs%253D&md5=f9230905a5656f9fe0e487967ecae356
        (e) Cui, Y. J.; Yue, Y. F.; Qian, G. D.; Chen, B. L. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 1126– 1162 DOI: 10.1021/cr200101d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6e
        Luminescent Functional Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Cui, Yuanjing; Yue, Yanfeng; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 1126-1162CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The authors discuss the title topic and applications such as LEDs and luminescent sensors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXnslKitr8%253D&md5=255200f12ee460fd90a29655c2b685dc
      7. 7
        (a) Ockwig, N. W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, O.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2005, 38, 176– 182 DOI: 10.1021/ar020022l
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7a
        Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
        Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXksFSgsg%253D%253D&md5=13530d98a4733672738db281372887ae
        (b) Carlucci, L.; Ciani, G.; Proserpio, D. M. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 246, 247– 289 DOI: 10.1016/S0010-8545(03)00126-7
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7b
        Polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chemistry
        Carlucci, Lucia; Ciani, Gianfranco; Proserpio, Davide M.
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 247-289CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review is presented on polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chem. The use of crystal engineering concepts produced a variety of coordination networks, many of which exhibit novel and fascinating types of entanglements of individual motifs. This review analyses the structures of a no. of entangled polymeric networks reported in these years by many groups. A topol. classification of the different interlocked and interweaved species is attempted. Wide classes of polycatenated and polythreaded species were recognized and other phenomena, as polyknotting (self-penetration) and interweaving of 1-dimensional chains, are also discussed. Unexpected topol. features and new linkages, that were previously overviewed, were discovered, including the first examples of infinite Borromean links.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpt1Gitr0%253D&md5=5727cc4be054c01d955b47f3cd366bc5
      8. 8
        (a) Thirumurugan, A.; Natarajan, S. J. Mater. Chem. 2005, 15, 4588– 4594 DOI: 10.1039/b510146h
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8a
        Hydrothermal synthesis, structure and luminescent properties of one-dimensional lanthanide benzenedicarboxylates, [M(NO3)M2(C12H8N2)2][(C8H4O4)4]·H2O, (M = La, Pr), possessing infinite M-O-M linkages
        Thirumurugan, A.; Natarajan, Srinivasan
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2005), 15 (43), 4588-4594CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A hydrothermal reaction of a mixt. of M(NO3)3, 1,2-dicyanobenzene, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-BDC), 1,10-phenanthroline and piperazine gave rise to a new compd., [M(NO3)M2(C12H8N2)2][(C8H4O4)4]·H2O, (M = La, I and Pr, II). The structure is built up from the connectivity of MOn polyhedra by sharing an edge or face. The metal atoms are coordinated by 1,10-phenanthroline or nitrate groups along with the phthalates resulting in an infinite 1-dimensional M-O-M chain. The crystal structure is stabilized by π···π and CH···π interactions. The authors' preliminary studies of the Eu3+/Tb3+ doped samples (in place of La3+), indicate that interesting red/pink or green luminescence can obtained by excitation at 252 nm. The luminescence behavior probably results from the ligand-sensitized metal-centered emission.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFKqt77K&md5=02e39fa8377d047b4dbb362a1e895ac6
        (b) Forster, P. M.; Cheetham, A. K. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 457– 459 DOI: 10.1002/1521-3773(20020201)41:3<457::AID-ANIE457>3.0.CO;2-W
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8b
        Open-framework nickel succinate, [Ni7(C4H4O4)6(OH)2(H2O)2]·2H2O: a new hybrid material with three-dimensional Ni-O-Ni connectivity
        Forster, Paul M.; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (3), 457-459CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A cryst. open-framework nickel succinate , [Ni7L6(OH)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, was prepd. using a biphasic (cyclohexanol/water) system. The crystal structure was detd. showing the structure to consist of layers of edge-sharing NiO6 octahedra forming rings connected by isolated corner sharing NiO6 octahedra creating unidimensional pores lined by methylene groups of the succinate. The nickel succinate was further characterized by thermal anal. and magnetic susceptibility measurements.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhtlWrs7c%253D&md5=e0c6da30b70d3951bd4e0fae3b917da0

        8d
        A building-up process in open-framework metal carboxylates that involves a progressive increase in dimensionality
        Dan, Meenakshi; Rao, C. N. R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (2), 281-285CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The zero-dimensional metal carboxylate (C4N2H12)3[Zn2(C2O4)5]·8H2O (C4N2H12 = diprotonated piperazine) is shown to transform into higher-dimensional structures including the helical (C4N2H12)2[Zn2(C2O4)4]·3H2O (2), the honeycomb-like (C4N2H12)3[Zn2(C2O4)7]·4H2O (3) and the three-dimensional network structure of (C4N2H12)[Zn2(C2O4)3] (4), thereby indicating the presence of a progressive building-up process. Also obtained from NiO and propionic acid are the dimer [Ni(CH3CH2CO2)2(H2O)] (5) and the one-dimensional chain structure [Ni(CH3CH2CO2)2] (6). The mol. structures of 2-6 were detd. by X-ray crystallog.
