        Synthesis, crystal structures, luminescence and catalytic properties of two d10 metal coordination polymers constructed from mixed ligands
        Wang, Xiao-xiao; Zhang, Ming-xi; Yu, Baoyi; Van Hecke, Kristof; Cui, Guang-hua
        Spectrochimica Acta, Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy (2015), 139 (), 442-448CODEN: SAMCAS; ISSN:1386-1425. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Two new coordination polymers [Cd(bmb)(hmph)]n (1), {[Ag(bmb)]·H2btc}n (2) (bmb = 1,4-bis(2-methylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, H2hmph = homophthalic acid, H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods, IR spectroscopy, TGA, XRPD and elemental anal.         40a
        Large breathing effects in three-dimensional porous hybrid matter: facts, analyses, rules and consequences
        Ferey, Gerard; Serre, Christian
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1380-1399CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This crit. review focuses on a strange behavior of crystd. solid matter: its reversible swelling with large magnitude. This will be of interest for experts in porous solids but also for solid state chemists and physicists. Some examples, classified according to the dimensionality of the inorg. subnetwork, present the general requirements and the structural rules which govern the existence of this phenomenon. Its consequences concern specific applications related to sensors, energy savings, sustainable development and health (100 refs.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        40b
        Soft porous crystals
        Horike, Satoshi; Shimomura, Satoru; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Nature Chemistry (2009), 1 (9), 695-704CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The field of host-guest complexation is intensely attractive from diverse perspectives, including materials science, chem. and biol. The uptake and encapsulation of guest species by host frameworks are being investigated for a wide variety of purposes, including sepn. and storage using zeolites, and recognition and sensing by enzymes in soln. Here we focus on the concept of the cooperative integration of 'softness' and 'regularity'. Recent developments on porous coordination polymers (or metal-org. frameworks) have provided the inherent properties that combine these features. Such soft porous crystals exhibit dynamic frameworks that are able to respond to external stimuli such as light, elec. fields or the presence of particular species, but they are also cryst. and can change their channels reversibly while retaining high regularity. We discuss the relationship between the structures and properties of these materials in view of their practical applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVGnt7vK&md5=c1f813fb0eef80c8a2456fc7f2a0c34c

        41
        Predicting aqueous aluminum concentrations in natural waters
        Cronan, Christopher S.; Walker, William J.; Bloom, Paul R.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1986), 324 (6093), 140-3CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
        A 2-component equil. model for predicting Al spatial and temporal variability in natural waters involves a solid-phase humic adsorbent and an Al(OH)3 mineral phase. Inputs for the model are soln. pH, Cu-extractable org. Al, and the titratable CO2H content of soil humus. This model will typically apply to surface org. horizons and peaty hydrol. source areas, whereas the inorg. soly. model will be appropriate for lower mineral soil horizons and for the groundwater zone.

        41b
        Aluminum: Impacts and Disease
        Nayak, Prasunpriya
        Environmental Research (2002), 89 (2), 101-115CODEN: ENVRAL; ISSN:0013-9351. (Elsevier Science)
        A review. Al is the most widely distributed metal in the environment and is extensively used in modern daily life. Al enters into the body from the environment and from diet and medication. However, there is no known physiol. role for Al within the body and hence this metal may produce adverse physiol. effects. The impact of Al on neural tissues is well reported but studies on extraneural tissues are not well summarized. In this review, the impacts of Al on humans and its impact on major physiol. systems are summarized and discussed. The neuropathologies assocd. with high brain Al levels, including structural, biochem., and neurobehavioral changes, were summarized. In addn., the impact of Al on the musculoskeletal system, respiratory system, cardiovascular system, hepatobiliary system, endocrine system, urinary system, and reproductive system are discussed.

        Kessler, M. A. Anal. Chem. 1999, 71, 1540– 1543 DOI: 10.1021/ac971313o
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43
        Probing the Dissociation State of Acid-Base Indicators by Time-Resolved Lanthanide Luminescence: A Convenient Transduction Scheme for Optical Chemical Sensors
        Kessler, Manfred A.
        Analytical Chemistry (1999), 71 (8), 1540-1543CODEN: ANCHAM; ISSN:0003-2700. (American Chemical Society)
        The paper describes a new method for the optical measurement of pH based on time-resolved luminescence. The intense line emission of a europium terpyridine chelate is strongly quenched by bromothymol blue (BTB). Since only the blue base form acts as a quencher, the decay time of the luminescence directly reflects the protonation state of BTB and, hence, the pH of the soln. The exptl. results are in good agreement with a theor. model that accommodates both the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation and the Stern-Volmer law. Decay time-based response curves have the same sigmoidal shape as conventional titrn. curves, but their apparent pKa is shifted to lower pH, depending on the total concn. of BTB used. All luminescence decay curves featured single-exponential decay. With 8 μmol/L BTB, decay times decreased from 1172 μs at pH 2.60 to 120 μs at pH 8.94, and the apparent pKa shifted from 7.0 to 6.1. A Stern-Volmer quenching const. of 9.55 × 105 was obtained for the base form of BTB. The method appears particularly useful as a transduction scheme for optical chem. sensors, since it makes conventional indicator dyes available to decay time-based sensing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXhvVeisro%253D&md5=d53c9f95ff6a8662e8f35f7773f3baee
      44. 44
        (a) Razek, T.; Spear, S.; Hassan, S. S. M.; Arnold, M. A. Talanta 1999, 48, 269– 275 DOI: 10.1016/S0039-9140(98)00245-8
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44a
        Selective measurement of chromium(VI) by fluorescence quenching of ruthenium
        Razek, Taha M. A.; Spear, Scott; Hassan, Saad S. M.; Arnold, Mark A.
        Talanta (1999), 48 (2), 269-275CODEN: TLNTA2; ISSN:0039-9140. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A flow injection method is described for the selective measurement of Cr(VI) in aq. solns. This method is based on the dynamic quenching of Ru(II) fluorescence. The detection limit is 0.43 ppm and 40 samples can be analyzed per h. Selectivity is demonstrated over ferrous, Ni, cupric and Zn cations and no effect is obsd. from sulfate, chloride, borate and phosphate. Some interference quenching was measured for cyanide and nitrate, but the method is more responsive to Cr(VI) by factors of 10.2 and 82, resp. The effects of soln. pH, carrier stream flow rate and Ru concn. are demonstrated. Results indicate the method is suitable for measuring Cr(VI) in effluents from electroplating baths.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXpsVymug%253D%253D&md5=919f73d2ee90a53beed14654db8f8c49
        (b) Hassan, S. S. M.; Abdel-Shafi, A. A.; Mohammed, A. H. K. Talanta 2005, 67, 696– 702 DOI: 10.1016/j.talanta.2005.03.019
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44b
        Flow injection fluorometric determination of chromium(VI) in electroplating baths by luminescence quenching of tris(2,2'-bipyridyl)ruthenium(II)
        Hassan, Saad S. M.; Abdel-Shafi, Ayman A.; Mohammed, Ayman H. K.
        Talanta (2005), 67 (4), 696-702CODEN: TLNTA2; ISSN:0039-9140. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A sensitive and selective luminescence quenching method is developed and used for manual and flow injection anal. (FIA) of Cr(VI) by reaction with [Ru(bpy)3]2+. The emission peak of Ru(II) at 595 nm is linearly decreased as a function of Cr(VI) concn. This permits detn. of Cr(VI) ion over the concn. range 0.1-20 μg ml-1 with a detection limit of 33 ng ml-1. The quenching process is due to an electron transfer from the luminescent [Ru(bpy)3]2+ complex ion to Cr(VI) giving the nonluminescent [Ru(bpy)3]3+ complex ion. Selectivity for Cr(VI) over many anions and transition, alkali and alk. earth metal cations is demonstrated. High concn. levels of sulfate, chloride, borate, acetate, phosphate, nitrate, cyanide, Pb2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ni2+ and Mn2+ ions are tolerated. The effects of soln. pH and [Ru(bpy)3]2+ reagent concn. were examd. and the reaction conditions are optimized. Validation of the method according to the quality assurance stds. show suitability of the proposed method for use in the quality control assessment of Cr(VI) in complex matrixes without prior treatment. The method is successfully applied to det. Cr(VI) in electroplating baths using flow injection anal. Results with a mean std. deviation of ±0.6% were obtained which compare fairly well with data obtained using at. absorption spectrometry.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXpsFylu7Y%253D&md5=d06f4ed5489014c015db60d3a485bb71
      45. 45
        Shi, P. F.; Hu, H. C.; Zhang, Z. Y.; Xiong, G.; Zhao, B. Chem. Commun. 2015, 51, 3985– 3988 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC09081K
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Heterometal-organic frameworks as highly sensitive and highly selective luminescent probes to detect I- ions in aqueous solutions
        Shi, Peng-Fei; Hu, Huan-Cheng; Zhang, Zhan-Yun; Xiong, Gang; Zhao, Bin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2015), 51 (19), 3985-3988CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two cationic heterometal-org. frameworks (Eu-Zn (1·NO3-) and Tb-Zn (2·NO3-)) with NO3- counter-anions in the channels are structurally and luminously characterized. Both of them can serve as highly sensitive and highly selective luminescent probes for detecting I- ions in aq. solns. In particular, 2·NO3- can selectively and reversibly detect I- with a fast response time of just 10 s and an extremely low detection limit of 0.001 ppm. Mechanism studies reveal that I- is quickly oxidized to form I3- with the help of 1·NO3- or 2·NO3-, leading to luminescence quenching. This represents the first report of MOF-based luminescent probes for the detection of I- in aq. solns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlsFyitA%253D%253D&md5=6e68990880d9cd5fca58d610e3530ffe
      46. 46
        (a) Jiang, H. L.; Feng, D.; Wang, K.; Gu, Z. Y.; Wei, Z.; Chen, Y. P.; Zhou, H. C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 13934– 13938 DOI: 10.1021/ja406844r
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46a
        An Exceptionally Stable, Porphyrinic Zr Metal-Organic Framework Exhibiting pH-Dependent Fluorescence
        Jiang, Hai-Long; Feng, Dawei; Wang, Kecheng; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Wei, Zhangwen; Chen, Ying-Pin; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (37), 13934-13938CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A reaction between a ZrIV salt and a porphyrinic tetracarboxylic acid leads to a metal-org. framework (MOF) with two types of open channels, representing a MOF featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The MOF is formulated as Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(OH)4(H2O)4(H2TCPP)2 (denoted as PCN-225) and it's Zn-contg. deriv. is denoted as PCN-225(Zn). The MOFs remains intact in both boiling H2O and aq. solns. with pH ranging from 1 to 11, a remarkably extensive pH range that a MOF can sustain. Given its exceptional stability and pH-dependent fluorescent intensity, the MOF can potentially be applied in fluorescent pH sensing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlChtLzI&md5=e5a2d00475d89e88c8be9d15d63dd4e7
        (b) Wang, J. Q.; Huang, L.; Xue, M.; Wang, Y.; Gao, L.; Zhu, J. H.; Zou, Z. J. Phys. Chem. C 2008, 112, 5014– 5022 DOI: 10.1021/jp7099948
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46b
        Architecture of a Hybrid Mesoporous Chemosensor for Fe3+ by Covalent Coupling Bis-Schiff Base PMBA onto the CPTES-Functionalized SBA-15
        Wang, Jian-Qiang; Huang, Li; Xue, Min; Wang, Ying; Gao, Ling; Zhu, Jian Hua; Zou, Zhigang
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2008), 112 (13), 5014-5022CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel hybrid mesoporous material PMBA-SBA was designed and synthesized by immobilizing bis-Schiff base N,N'-(1,4-phenylenedimethyli- dyne)bis(1,4-benzenediamine) (PMBA) within the channels of (γ-chloropropyl)triethoxysilane (CPTES) modified SBA-15. TEM images of the hybrid materials illustrated the reservation of the hexagonal ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15 after functionalization. The characteristic absorbance of the C:N stretching vibration of the Schiff base was obsd. in the IR spectrum of the hybrid materials, indicating the successful immobilization of PMBA in the mesoporous composite, while the XPS spectra confirmed that the linkage of the PMBA mol. within the channels of CPTES-functionalized SBA-15 is realized by forming a covalent bond between amino and chloropropyl groups. This novel mesoporous material PMBA-SBA showed a high selectivity to Fe3+ ion, which results from a dramatic fluorescence quenching by the addn. of Fe3+ ion upon the suspensions of PMBA-SBA. A good linearity between the fluorescence intensity of PMBA-SBA and the concn. of Fe3+ ion is constructed, which enables this hybrid martial as a fluorescence chemosensor for detecting the Fe3+ ion with a satisfactory detection limit of 1.98 × 10-6 M. Judged on the linear equation, the fluorescence quenching of the hybrid material by Fe3+ ion progresses by static quenching forming a non-fluorescence complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXivV2ns74%253D&md5=7c8677db744387ed3fc5f982b2ceae8a
        (c) Lu, Z. Z.; Zhang, R.; Li, Y. Z.; Guo, Z. J.; Zheng, H. G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 4172– 4174 DOI: 10.1021/ja109437d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46c
        Solvatochromic Behavior of a Nanotubular Metal-Organic Framework for Sensing Small Molecules
        Lu, Zhen-Zhong; Zhang, Rui; Li, Yi-Zhi; Guo, Zi-Jian; Zheng, He-Gen
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4172-4174CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A nanotubular metal-org. framework (MOF), {[(WS4Cu4)I2(dptz)3]·DMF}n (dptz = 3,6-di(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, DMF = DMF) for sensing small solvent mols. is presented. When accommodating different solvent mols. as guests, the resulting inclusion compds. exhibit different colors depending on the solvent guests, and more interestingly, the band gaps of these solvent-included complexes are in linear correlation with the polarity of the guest solvents. The solvent mols. can be sensed by the changes of UV-visible spectra of the corresponding inclusion compds., showing a new way of signal transduction as a new kind of sensor. The sensing by such a MOF occurs within the channel-contg. material rather than on the external surface.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXislGntbk%253D&md5=039fac5f14b14b2f4199d5ed2fb15612
